Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i \omega t} \\) where \\( \omega \\) is a complex constant. We analyze the behavior of this system when subjected to a Fourier transform, defined as \\( \mathcal{F}(z)(\xi) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-i \xi t} z(t) \, dt \\).

If only the Fourier transformed result \\( \mathcal{F}(z)(\xi) \\) is known to peak at \\( \xi = \omega \\), can we deduce that the function \\( z(t) \\) was \\( e^{i \omega t} \\) before transformation?
Explanation: The peaking of \\( \mathcal{F}(z)(\xi) \\) at \\( \omega \\) indicates that the original function had a frequency component of \\( \omega \\). Due to the properties of the Fourier transform, it is the exclusive frequency of the original oscillating function.
